headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Fani Willis Testifying At A Hearing. Aired 3:30-4p ET

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, DEFENSE ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: I'm not asking about reimbursement or after. He used his credit card to buy the cruise and buy the flight, correct?

utterances.speaker: FANI WILLIS, DISTRICT ATTORNEY OF FULTON COUNTY
utterances.sentences: I have no idea how he paid for it.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: If it's a credit card, if it's a debit card, but certainly he called his cruise agent. You know, like how many people have a cruise agent? He calls his cruise agent, tells them where they want to go. They tell him what's booked.You have to remember he didn't just he paid for that initial was me, him, and his mother.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And then after that cruise, you all flew to Aruba and spent a couple days in hotel there, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Right. And his mother was not happy (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: He initially paid for that. He initially paid for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: For Aruba. Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So let's talk about both of those. I know he initially paid for it. Did you pay him back?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: For the cruise and for Aruba. Yes, I gave him his money before we ever went on that trip.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You gave him cash before you ever went on the trip?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And so when you got cash to pay him back on these trips, would you go to the ATM?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, lady.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You would not go to the ATM?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Fulton County and the state of Georgia both pay me direct deposits.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So the cash that you would pay him, you wouldn't get it out of the bank?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I have money in my house.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You have money in your house. So it was just money that was there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: When you meet my father, he's going to tell you as a woman, you should always have, which I don't have. So let's don't tell him that. You should have at least six months in cash at your house at all time.Now, I don't know why this old black man feels like that, but he does. When we were growing up, my daddy had three safes in the house. So my father's bought me a lock box and I always keep cash in the house. Now, I don't do it to the degree that my father would do it. So he would probably be ashamed with me, but I always have cash at the house. That has been, I don't know, all my life. If you're a woman and you go on a date with a man, you better have $200 in your pocket. So if that man acts up, you can go where you want to go. So I keep cash in my house and I don't keep cash as good in my purse like I used to. I don't go on many dates, but when you go on a date, you should have cash in your pocket.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So my question was, where did that cash originally come from? If it hadn't come out of the bank.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Cash is fungible. It have cash for years in my house. So for me to tell you the source of when it comes from, when you go to Publix then you buy something, you have $50, you throw it in there. It's been my whole life.When I took out a large amount of money on my first campaign, I kept some of the cash of that. Like, to tell you, I just have cash in my house. I don't have as much today as I would normally have, but I'm building back up now. So you just put money in. It's a very good practice. I would advise it to all women.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So you can't identify when you came into this cash or where the cash came from?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I didn't say I couldn't identify it. Nobody gives me anything. I am sure that the source of the money is always the word sweat and tears of me.What you asked me for is, when did the money go in there? What I am trying to tell you is -- so I got divorced in 2005 from my husband.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no. It's important. You said, where did the money come from, and I need to tell you where the money came from.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She just answered your question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And so for many, many years, I have kept money in my house. That money in my worst days has probably only been $500 or $1,000. At my best days, I probably had $15,000 in my house I keep cash.At all times, there's going to be cash in my house. Or wherever I'm laying my head.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The money that you paid, Mr. Wade, the cash in October of 2022, you do not know where that money came from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I do know where it came from. It came from my sweat and tears.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You know which job it came from. Did it come from Fulton County or did it come from a private job?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: It came from, I'm not a -- what are you talking about? So it could have come from a private job because before I was DA, I was in private practice. So I earned money during that time period, that's probably in there.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You don't know where it came from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What do you mean I don't know where it came from? I absolutely didn't.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT MCAFEE, JUDGE, FULTON COUNTY, GEORGIA SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: I understand the situation. We can move on.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Thanks. Same with the Aruba. You don't know where that cash came from either, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Ma'am, you are mischaracterizing my testimony greatly. I'm not going to allow you to mischaracterize my testimony. I know that I keep money in my house. The amounts of money I gave Mr. Wade, it was never that serious. I don't think I've ever handed him more than $2,500 in a reimbursement.So we're not talking about $20,000 in cash. I don't have $20,000 in cash right now. Most I ever gave him -- I know I gave him $2,500 when we went to Belize because we went to one hotel and then we went to a second hotel. That $2,500, I actually gave him while we were still in Belize. I know that the Aruba trip, the one that you described with his mom, I think I gave him about $2,000 for that trip for like total.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: His mom went to Aruba with you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: The Aruba trip. So I consider that to be one trip.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So I consider that one trip. We didn't like come back to Atlanta and leave. We went -- we flew down to Miami, we got on a cruise ship. We spent a couple of days with his mama. We came back to Miami. When we came back to Miami, either that day or the next day, we flew to Aruba.We spent a few days in Aruba and we came back. That was really one trip. Even though we went two places, it was one trip.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So let's talk about the California trip. Is that when you were moving your daughter out to California when you all went -- or did you have two trips to California?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: My daughter doesn't live in California.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did she ever live in California?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm not discussing to you the location of my child.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, how many times did you go with Mr. Wade to California?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Once.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you all stayed in Napa Valley and he paid for the plane tickets in the hotel?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He paid for the plane tickets and the hotel.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And what did you pay for on that trip?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I gave him much less cash that time, probably $400 or $500. And then I paid for a bunch of stuff. I think we did two different wine tours that you do, which are pretty expensive. I think I bought him -- he likes wine. I don't really like wine, to be honest with you. I like Grey Goose.I bought him a bottle of wine while we were there and the sippings that you do. I can't remember how -- like four or five different places you go. I remember we went to this place that they do pairings. That was the most expensive thing that I think that we did while we were there. So they would pair -- they would pair champagne, chocolate and -- champagne, chocolate, and caviar. It was at three -- and it was like three different things. Sweden, Russia, someplace else, I'll make that up. But that was the most expensive thing we did that trip. And I paid for -- I paid for that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you pay cash? WILLIS

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think I -- but that trip did not cost me a lot of money. I might've took like $750 in cash on me because we weren't gone very long.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm just --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And then I --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'd only ask if you paid in cash. I don't even know the amount.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: When I travel, I always take cash.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And it's the cash that you keep in your house or do you keep it at the condo that you were living in?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So at that point, it wouldn't be at my house and I'm sorry if I was not clear. The money would be wherever I laid my head. So I wouldn't leave the money at the house. So if I was unclear, no, money's going to be where I stay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: How much did you pay for your trip to Panama?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: To where?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Panama, I believe.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I didn't go to Panama.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I may have the location wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I never went to Panama.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: After--

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Wade went to Panama with his frat brother.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Oh, he went to Panama with his frat brother. So tell me about, let's see. So I want to make sure I've got him. I've got Belize. You already covered Belize. You covered the --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So let me tell you our real trips. In October, we went with -- we went on the cruise with his mom. We got back from the cruise with his mom and we went to Aruba. I consider that one trip.Second trip, New Year's Eve. We went on the cruise to the Bahamas. That's the second trip. I'm going to make sure I get this right. Third trip, 100 percent on me, I think he might have spent $200 on that entire trip. We went to Belize. That was my trip. That was, you know, his 50th. And then Napa Valley, we went around May. I don't know the dates, but it seems to me like it was close to Mother's Day.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And those are the only trips?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So that the record is complete. I can remember one time driving to -- where were we? South Carolina and we met my sister for lunch with her man.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When was that?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And that's what I was going to ask you, your security detail. Did they take you to and from your house?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: They take -- well, so I haven't been able to enjoy my home.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Condo, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: In March --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Where you lay your head, did they take you to and from where you lay your head?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Ninety-nine percent of the time. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That is never in the history of ever happened, ever, OK?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Your security team has never taken him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: From my house? That's a lie. That's another --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: If they've ever taken him anywhere.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And I'm telling you that that's never happened.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So your security team has never taken him away then?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: My security team has never taken Mr. Wade from any place where I have lived and brought him here. Never. Not once. Not ever.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Have they ever taken the two of you together?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: To where?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Anywhere.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: We've left this building and for -- gone to lunch, but I go to lunch so rarely that that is a very rare occasion. I am sure.And let me be clear. It wouldn't just be Mr. Wade. So I'm sure my security team has taken me to lunch. Probably been a time I've left here. Seven o'clock, going to get something to eat. And I don't even know that they would have taken him or if he would have driven himself. But they've taken me to do that. But we're talking very few, very far in between. Most days I don't even eat lunch. And what I do is because my assistant has heated up some bags, something that I eat through meetings and eat in my office. It's not a practice of mine to go to lunch.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: During the time period that you were dating, would your security team ever take you two together anymore?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Never?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: If there was a lunch that occurred that I just described, if there was a meal that occurred that I just described, anything outside of that, and it needs to be very clear. Not often. Once, twice. Because I want to be over inclusive. I'm saying once or twice. I'm not certain that it happened, but I'd rather be over inclusive with you.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So your office objected to us getting Delta records for flights that you may have taken with Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) WILLIS

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So my question was, you have any prior --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I object to getting any personal records of mine.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: We're not dealing with privilege through a witness.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I'm not -- no, no. I'm not dealing with privilege. What we had offered to put them in camera for the court to review, and I just want to know if she has any problem.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: That's not something to deal with the witness.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. You have to file as part of your job something called an income and financial disclosure report, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you filed your first one. So you filed two today? Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Is it two or three? I probably would have filed '21, '22. And maybe I haven't filed '23 yet because isn't it due like June of the next year?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: April, I believe. So you filed -- let's see. You filed your first one. It looks like April 15th, 2022. And your second one, April 17th, 2023. Does that sound familiar?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't remember the dates, but you're an officer of the court. I'm going to hope you're telling the truth now.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: May I -- may I approach the witness?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: You're okay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I already gave the state a copy Exhibit 20 and 21. (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Can somebody bring me some -- yeah. That's a getting a little old. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Those are the ones that you filed?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: This looks like me for sure. Yes, ma'am. Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, we'd move to admit 20 and 21. MCAFEE

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Twenty is 2021. So it accounts for the time period, Your Honor, January the 1st, '21 through December the 31st, 2021. That is defendants Exhibit 20.Defendants Exhibit 2021. It accounts for the time period. January the 1st, 2022 through December the 1st of 2022.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Any objection to Exhibits 20 and 21?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Nope. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: From other council. And we're going to without objection.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes. When did your relationship -- your personal relationship with Mr. Wade end?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Let me just clarify that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And so I have a personal relationship with him as we speak right now.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: A romantic --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's what you're asking. I think that's what you're asking.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Romantic relationship. When did your romantic relationship with Mr. Wade end? Evident.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Me and Mr. Wade, we are good friends. My respect for him has grown over these seven weeks of attacks. We are very good friends. I think -- but for these attacks it would have been a friendship that as life goes you would have stopped having. I think that you have seen minute that we'll be friends to the day we die.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Your Honor --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let's --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- can we just have an answer to the question?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let me handle this (INAUDIBLE). Let's have a --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: She asked about a personal relationship.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: She asked when the romantic relationship ended. That's the question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Sometime in -- I'd say late summer of 2023. But I don't believe me in what you're really asking about. This is the salaciousness of all of this, right?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No. I'm just asking about your romantic relationship. When you stop dating.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I think that me and Mr. Wade -- so he's a man. He probably would say June or July. I would say we had a tough conversation in August.So that many in relationships at the end of physical intimacy. Women in relationships when that tough conversation takes place.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And where -- when -- did he come to, I guess, the condo, I'm not sure what you call the condo apartment. Would he come and stay at that condo or visit you there? I'm sorry visit you there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What condo? What apartment? I want to be clear.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So not your house. I know you classified one as house and one as condo. So I'm trying to use those terms.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: But there's been more than -- see what you don't understand is because of this case I got to move. And so I think --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, if you could ask a more precise question.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Please give me the time period.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wade visits you at the place you laid your head.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: When?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Has he ever visited you at the place you laid your head?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So let's be clear because you lied in this. Let me tell you which one you lied in right here. I think you're lying right here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, no (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. This is the truth. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: It is a lie. It is a lie.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ms. Willis. Mr. (INAUDIBLE), thank you. We're going to take five minutes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Be back in five.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Fireworks in court as we've listened to district attorney Fani Willis testifying regarding the details of her relationship with one of her lead prosecutors, Nathan Wade.The defense there asking her questions about when their relationship started, when their relationship ended. Fani Willis, at different points, becoming what the judge referred to as an adverse witness delving into different aspects of even her own family history trying to answer questions about why she reimbursed him with cash. Why it was that she moved out of her home at one point. This is getting deep into personal territory for the district attorney in a way that I bet she didn't anticipate when these charges were filed against former president Trump and his more than a dozen co- defendants.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: No. And I think probably the sound and I'm just going to paraphrase it --

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: This is explosive. Fani Willis is defiant. She is confrontational. And, frankly, she is persuasive this afternoon.This entirety of the proceedings, it was very clear that she was gunning to come in and testify. She is angry at the person who has brought these allegations against her. She is insulted by the notion that she is somehow sexually promiscuous. She is very irritated and leaving the fact that she herself feels as though she is being called to task and on trial. Here is the fundamental flaw of the allegations against her. There is no through line yet that has been established between her financial resources, Nathan Wade's financial resources, and how she may or may not have financially benefited. It is as if they are presuming that she started with a zero balance in her account. And only that which came in through this particular indictment is what she has to sustain her life and Nathan Wade. Why is that important? Because they're trying to suggest that she has financially benefited from hiring Nathan Wade and maybe even sustaining the indictment itself. Well, she has gone to clear strengths and clear lengths, excuse me, as did Nathan Wade to suggest that there are multiple sources of income. She talks about her private practice in the background, the source of cash in her home and beyond, as a way and a means of actually providing for herself. She was very defiant and saying, he never took me anywhere. It had a real feel, frankly, of Diana Ross and Mahogany, if you ask me about the idea of she's been plenty of places. Has she not? She talked about Nathan Wade and his own resources and beyond. But I want to just stress to everyone. Do you know how fundamentally dangerous it is for a prosecutor to tell and expose her personal life? Just think of the people that she is confronting, that she is prosecuting. I remember being nine months pregnant when someone saying to me, congratulations, and me saying, I'm not pregnant. That's how private you want to keep your life, because every single iota, every morsel you convey to the world can be used against you. You could be sitting there in front of a jury, in front of a defendant, and now your personal life is on display. How do you think that will be used against you? How can your family now be vulnerable? She's talking about where she keeps her money in her home. Gee, there is a security detail. This is extraordinarily dangerous. It tells you the very high stakes of where she is in this moment, that she is here in this moment. And let's just be very clear. She's not pulling any pensions. And I tell you, I really don't think that this judge was intending to even force her to testify today. It is very clear that she wanted to testify. She believes she's being lied about. This is all undermining, she believes her credibility. And look, as Nick Valencia said multiple times about the day today, and we all have, we are not talking about the underlying charges against the former president of the United States and 17 other code defendants, several of whom have already pled guilty.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. We have the exact quote that Brianna mentioned as we await for the proceedings to pick up again to the point that Laura was just making. Fani Willis trying to bring the focus back to the actual content of the case itself, objecting to a comment made by one of the defense attorneys about getting personal records, saying that that attorney has been intrusive in a people's personal lives.Actually, I think Judge Scott McAfee is making some comments. Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: -- of a courtroom. We all know what professionalism looks like, what decorum looks like, and devoting ourselves to the rule of law and proper advocacy. I would urge everyone to keep those principles into mind, starting with the fact that we won't talk over each other.And from there, we'll get through this. Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So you want to start with the lie that he lived with me in South Fulton in 2019, the home he's never been to? That's one lie you told in your document. No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, I didn't ask her about that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, I want you to ask a very precise question. I think she's saying and answering that he did not live with her. So why don't we break that up into smaller parts?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I didn't ask about living.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What you put in your -- while we're talking about professionalism. No, while we're talking about professionalism, she put in three different documents he lived with me.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Oh, so you'll have more opportunity to respond. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And filed that with the court. Professionalism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He's never been to South Fulton. In 2019, I lived in South Fulton. He has never been to my residence in 2019, ever, not once. 2020 --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: In 2019, he's never been to your residence at any place?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I lived in my home in South Fulton before I started getting the threats that we're here. A house I paid for with my own sweat and tears. I'm no longer able to live there. But in 2019, I did. And in the two months of 2019, that I knew Mr. Wade three months, the beginning of October, all of November, and all of December, Mr. Wade never came to my house in South Fulton.Let me help you out. I lived there in 2020. He never came to my house in 2020. Let alone live with me as you put falsely in these documents. In the first three months of 2021, when I could still enjoy my home, Mr. Wade never came to South Fulton, and it is certainly a lie that he lived with me.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So in 2020, let's -- so you said 2019. 2020. Did Mr. Wade ever visit you at a place that you were --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He has never been to my home in South Fulton. 2020 was before I knew that a phone call was going to be made, and I was going to have to abandon my home. As a result thereof, he never visited, lived that, came to or has seen South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You qualified that with your home in South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's where I lived in 2020.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: 2020, did he ever visit you at a place that you resided to?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: OK. I don't understand you want to give me guys. In 2020 --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: So she's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I lived in South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's the only place I lived in South Fulton. That's before I had to abandon my home, Judge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And at my home in South Fulton --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: well, we're going to clarify this. WILLIS

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Willis, that's -- I'm going to have to caution you. That's going to be my first time I have to caution you. We have to listen to the questions as I ask. And if this happens again and again, I'm going to have no choice but to strike your testimony.So I need to break this down. Ms. Merchant's question, I believe, is asking whether you lived anywhere other than South Fulton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I did not live anywhere but South Fulton, Georgia in 2020. That was before I began my prosecution of this case. And I -- it was my plan to only live there.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did Mr. Wade ever visit you at the condo that you leased from this year being?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He visited that condo, yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: He did?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did he ever spend the night at that condo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Just visited?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, but he did visit for sure.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you ever go out to eat together other than the lunches you talked about --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: -- during 2019 or 2020?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I would think that we probably went to lunch but it wouldn't have been -- let me think, 2019. I'm going to say, I don't know. I'm going to say we probably broke bread someplace in 2019. I don't remember it but it seemed like we would have broke bread sometime in 2019.So I'm going to say yes, although I have no recollection. But it seems to me I got -- I go out to eat and drink with pretty much everyone. So I'm going to say yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Outside of the vacations that we've already talked about, did you ever go out to dinner with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I mentioned to you that I will --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object at what time period? Like we're asking very big questions. I thought we were treating the witness as hostile under 611. We're no longer doing that. So we're going to go back and forth. We need to be more specific with our questions and we're going to treat her as hostile.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ms. Merchant, it's not so much. I think you can elect between leading and opening the questions, but I think we are still wondering about. And I think we need to get back on track of focusing on the financial benefit or the relationship.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And my next question about if you did go out to dinner, who paid when you went out to dinner?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He paid, I paid.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You both paid?
